Chapter 14, Part 2: The Buddha Speaks on Entering the Womb
At that time, the World-Honored One again told Nanda:
Since you now understand the suffering of entering the womb and the suffering of birth, you should know that those who undergo birth in the womb are extremely miserable.

When first born, whether a boy or a girl, falling into people's hands or in clothes, placed in the sun or in the shade, put in a rocking chair or on a bed, in the arms, because of these causes and conditions, all experience sour, spicy, painful, extreme suffering.
Nanda!

Like an ox whose skin is flayed, living near a wall is eaten by wall insects, if near trees and grass, tree and grass insects eat it, if living in the open, various insects bite it, all experiencing suffering and distress.

The first birth is also like this, being washed with warm water, experiencing great suffering and distress, like a leper whose skin is ulcerated, pus and blood flowing everywhere, and being beaten with a stick, experiencing extreme pain and distress.
After being born, he drinks the blood and filth of the mother and grows up.
As for the blood and filth, in the holy Dharma and Vinaya, it is precisely breast milk.
Nandana!
Since there are such various extreme sufferings, not a single one is enjoyable. Who has wisdom and would give rise to attachment to this sea of suffering, constantly revolving without rest?
After seven days of birth, there are already eighty thousand worms inside the body, moving horizontally and vertically, devouring.
Nandana!
There is a kind of worm called hair-eater, which resides in the roots of the hair and always eats the hair.
There are two kinds of worms, one called hidden treasure and the other called coarse head, which reside in the head and always eat the head.
There is a kind of worm called circling the eyes, which resides in the eyes and always eats the eyes.
There are four kinds of worms, one called driving away, another called running, another called house, and another called perfect, which reside in the brain and always eat the brain.
There is a type of worm named rice leaf, which lives in the ears and eats the ears.
There is a type of worm named hidden mouth, which lives in the nose and eats the nose.
There are two types of worms, one named throwing far and one named throwing everywhere, which live in the lips and eat the lips.

There is a type of worm named honey leaf, which lives in the teeth and eats the teeth.ğŸ”½There is a type of worm named wooden mouth, which lives in the roots of the teeth and eats the roots of the teeth.ğŸ”½There is a type of worm named needle mouth, which lives in the tongue and eats the tongue.
There is a type of worm named sharp mouth, which lives in the roots of the tongue and eats the roots of the tongue.

There is a type of worm named round hand, which lives in the palate and eats the palate.ğŸ”½There are two types of worms, one named webbed hand and one named half-bent, which live in the palms and eat the palms.ğŸ”½There are two types of worms, one named short hanging and one named long hanging, which live in the wrists and eat the wrists.
There are two types of worms, one named distant arm and one named near arm, which live in the arms and eat the arms.

There are two worms, one called desirous of swallowing and one called already swallowed, which live in the throat and eat the throat.ğŸ”½There are two worms, one called having enmity and one called great enmity, which live in the chest and eat the chest.
There are two worms, one called conch and one called conch mouth, which live in the flesh and eat the flesh.

There are two worms, one called having color and one called having strength, which live in the blood and eat the blood.ğŸ”½There are two worms, one called valiant and one called fragrant mouth, which live in the sinews and eat the sinews.
There are two worms, one called not tall and one called downward mouth, which live in the spine and eat the spine.
There are two worms, both called fat color, which live in the fat and eat the fat.
There is one worm called yellow color which lives in the gall and eats the gall.ğŸ”½There is one worm called pearl, which lives in the kidneys and eats the kidneys.
There is one worm called great pearl, which lives in the waist and eats the waist.
There is a type of worm called 'not yet reached' that lives in and feeds on the spleen.
There are four types of worms, called 'water life', 'large water life', 'needle mouth', and 'knife mouth', that live in and feed on the intestines.
There are five types of worms, called 'full moon', 'moon face', 'luminous', 'luminous face', and 'separate dwelling', that live in and feed on the right side of the body.

There are also five worms with the same names that live in and feed on the left side of the body.ğŸ”½There are four worms, called 'piercing front', 'piercing back', 'piercing solid', and 'piercing dwelling', that live in and feed on the bones.ğŸ”½There are four types of worms, called 'great white', 'small white', 'heavy cloud', and 'foul smell', that live in and feed on the blood vessels.
There are four types of worms, called 'lion', 'equipped strength', 'rapid arrow', and 'lotus', that live in and feed on the liver.

There are two kinds of worms, one called Anzhi and the other called Jinshi, that live in the mature intestines and eat the mature intestines.ğŸ”½There are four kinds of worms, one called Yan-kou, the second called Yun-kou, the third called Wang-kou, and the fourth called Que-kou, that live in the urethra and eat urine.
There are four kinds of worms, one called Ying-zuo, the second called Da-zuo, the third called Xiao-xing, and the fourth called Xiao-zhu, that live in the anus and eat feces.
There are two kinds of worms.ğŸ”½One is called Hei-kou.
The other is called Da-kou.
They live in the thighs and eat the thighs.
There are two kinds of worms, one called Lai and the other called Xiao-lai, that live in the knees and eat the knees.
There is one kind of worm called Yu-gen that lives in the shins and eats the shins.
There is one kind of worm called Hei-xiang that lives in the feet and eats the feet.
Nanduo!
This body is very disgusting.
Beings of this type always have eighty thousand families of worms that eat day and night, causing the body to be hot, emaciated, exhausted, hungry, and thirsty.
Moreover, the mind has various kinds of suffering, worry, despair, and many illnesses appear, with no good doctor able to cure them.
Nanda!
In the great ocean of existence within birth and death, there is such suffering. How can one take pleasure in this?

Moreover, one is seized by the illnesses of various spirits, namely, the spirits of the gods, dragons, and the eight classes of beings, as well as various ghosts and spirits, up to the ká¹£etrapÄlas, pÅ«tanÄs, and other birds and beasts that are possessed by the spirits, or one is afflicted by the sun, moon, stars, and constellations.
These ghosts and spirits create various illnesses that afflict the body and mind, which are difficult to describe in detail.
The Buddha told Nanda:

Who would enjoy entering a mother's womb in saá¹ƒsÄra, enduring extreme hardship, being born in this way, growing up in this way, drinking the mother's blood in her milk and various foods, mistakenly giving rise to thoughts of beauty, gradually reaching maturity?
Even if the body obtains comfort and health, with food and clothing to one's liking and a lifespan of a hundred years, within this life, sleep reduces it by half.

First as an infant, then as a child, gradually reaching adulthood, with worries, sadness, troubles, and various illnesses afflicting one, the countless hundreds of sufferings that touch one's body are difficult to describe completely.
When the internal sufferings of the body are difficult to endure, one does not wish to live and immediately seeks death.
Such a body has much suffering and little joy. Although it may temporarily remain, it will certainly perish.
Nanda!
Those who are born all die, without any permanence.
Even if one extends one's lifespan by nourishing it with medicine and food, one will ultimately not escape being killed by the king of death and sent to the empty field.
Therefore, you should know that birth has nothing pleasurable.
In the future, you should diligently accumulate provisions and not be negligent. Cultivate pure conduct and do not be lazy.
Always delight in practicing beneficial conduct, Dharma conduct, meritorious conduct, and purely wholesome conduct.
Always observe your own good and evil karma, keep it in mind, and do not let there be great regret later.
All that is loved and cherished will all be separated, and according to good and evil karma, one will go to the next world.
Nandi!
A lifespan of a hundred years has ten stages:
The first is the infant stage, lying in swaddling clothes.
The second is the child stage, delighting in childish play.
The third is the youth stage, experiencing various desires.
The fourth is the prime of life stage, vigorous and strong.
The fifth is the mature stage, with wisdom and eloquence.
The sixth is the accomplished stage, able to skillfully contemplate and devise strategies.
Seven is gradual decline, well knowing the rules.
Eight is decrepitude, with all affairs weakening.
Nine is extreme old age, with nothing one can do.
Ten is a hundred years, which is the position of impending death.
NandÄ!
The general outline and major positions are roughly explained like this.
Taking four months as one season, there are three hundred seasons in a hundred years, with each of spring, summer, and winter having a hundred.

A year of twelve months has a total of one thousand two hundred months. If counted by half-months, there are a total of two thousand four hundred half-months, with each of the three seasons having eight hundred half-months, totaling thirty-six thousand days and nights.
Eating twice a day, there are a total of seventy-two thousand times eating, although there are conditions of not eating, they are also included in the count.

Conditions of not eating refer to not eating out of anger and resentment, not eating due to suffering, or not getting what one seeks, not eating due to sleep, fasting, or playfulness, and not eating due to affairs.
Whether eating or not, they all come together, and the number of times one drinks one's mother's milk is so many.
If a person's life spans a hundred years, I have already fully explained the years, months, days and nights, and the number of meals. You should give rise to disgust.
Nan-t'o!

Thus, one grows up, and the body has many illnesses, namely, head, eyes, ears, nose, tongue, teeth, throat, chest, abdomen, hands, and feet, scabies, epilepsy, edema, cough, wind, jaundice, phlegm, many kinds of malaria, and pain in the limbs and joints.
Nan-t'o!
The human body has such illnesses and suffering.

There are also one hundred and one kinds of wind illnesses, one hundred and one kinds of jaundice illnesses, one hundred and one kinds of phlegm illnesses, and one hundred and one kinds of combined illnesses, totaling four hundred and four illnesses, which arise from within.
Nan-t'o!
The body is like a boil or arrow, formed from many illnesses, not staying for a moment, not abiding for a moment.
The body is impermanent, suffering, empty, and without self. It is always close to death and subject to decay and destruction, and cannot be cherished and loved.
Nanda!

Ordinary beings also experience such suffering upon birth, such as having their hands, feet, eyes, ears, nose, tongue, head, and limbs cut off, being imprisoned, chained, whipped, beaten, starved, thirsty, exhausted, cold, hot, rained on, bitten by mosquitoes and ants, blown by the wind, and encountering fierce beasts and other painful sensations. The various afflictions are immeasurable and boundless, difficult to describe in detail.

Sentient beings always delight in sinking in such a solid and painful state. Whatever they desire has suffering as its basis. Not knowing how to abandon it, they pursue it again. Day and night, their bodies and minds are tormented and troubled, and internal burning arises without rest.
Such are the sufferings of birth, old age, sickness, death, separation from what is loved, encountering what is hated, not obtaining what is sought, and the five aggregates of clinging.
In the four postures of walking, standing, sitting, and lying down, there is also suffering. If one always walks and does not stand, sit, or lie down, one will experience suffering without joy;

If one always stands and does not walk, sit, or lie down, if one sits and does not walk, stand, or lie down, if one lies down and does not walk, stand, or sit, one will experience extreme suffering without any comfort.
Nanda!

These are all abandoning suffering and seeking suffering. There is only the arising of suffering and the cessation of suffering. The continuity of conditioned factors arises through causes and conditions.

The TathÄgata understands this, and therefore teaches that the dharma of sentient beings' birth and death, conditioned factors are impermanent, not true and ultimate, are subject to change and decay, and cannot be preserved.
One should seek contentment, deeply give rise to disgust, and diligently seek liberation.
Nanda!

In the good destinies, the various kinds of beings are born in impure places, and the suffering is severe like this. The various kinds of deceptions are indescribable. How much more so for the complete description of the suffering endured by the beings in the three evil destinies - hungry ghosts, animals, and hell - which is difficult to endure.
Furthermore, Nanda!
There are four kinds of entering the mother's womb.
What are the four?

First, there are beings who enter with right mindfulness, abide with right mindfulness, and leave with right mindfulness.ğŸ”½Second, there are those who enter with right mindfulness, abide with right mindfulness, but leave with wrong mindfulness.
Third, there are those who enter with right mindfulness, abide with wrong mindfulness, and leave with right mindfulness.
Fourth, all three are with wrong mindfulness.
Who has right mindfulness in entering, abiding, and leaving?

It is like a certain type of ordinary sentient being who, by nature, loves to uphold precepts, frequently cultivates wholesome qualities, delights in doing superior things, performs various meritorious practices, and is extremely well-guarded. Always thinking straightforwardly and not being negligent, with great wisdom, at the time of death without regret one immediately receives rebirth, either as a seven-times-at-most stream-enterer, or as a family-to-family, or as a once-returner, or as a non-returner.

Because this person previously cultivated wholesome practices, at the time of the passing of life, although suffering comes and afflicts one with various pains and troubles, the mind is not scattered and ends with right mindfulness. Again, with right mindfulness one enters the mother's womb, understanding that all dharmas are born from karma, all arising from causes and conditions, always providing a dwelling place for various mÄras.
Nandimitra should know that this body is always a dwelling place of all impurities, the substance is not permanently abiding, it is a deluded object that deceives and confuses people.

This body is a machine made of bones, with sinews and blood vessels connecting the various holes, wrapped together with fat, flesh, and marrow, covered with skin to hide its faults. In a hot den, it is filled with impurities, with different positions of hair, body hair, nails, and teeth. Because of grasping at self and what belongs to self, it is always bound and pulled, unable to be free.

Constantly producing snot, saliva, filth, flowing sweat, yellow water, phlegm, rotten fat, kidneys, gall, liver, lungs, large intestine, small intestine, feces, urine, and other disgusting things, and various insects are all over it. The upper and lower holes always flow with foul odors.
The two viscera of raw and cooked are covered with thin skin, which is called a latrine.
You should observe that when you eat, your teeth chew, moisten with saliva, and swallow into the throat, mixing with marrow and brain, flowing into the stomach.
Like a dog biting a dry bone, mistakenly giving rise to the thought of deliciousness. When the food reaches the navel, it vomits and covers the top, and then swallows it back.
Nanda!

This body originally comes from the kalala, arbuda, peÅ›in, ghana, and praÅ›ÄkhÄ, impure and filthy substances that grow and develop, from infancy to old age and death, revolving and bound like a dark pit, like a stinking well.
Always nourishing with salty, bland, bitter, spicy, sour, and other food flavors.
Moreover, the fire in the mother's womb burns and cooks the body, and the impure cesspool always brings the suffering of heat.
When the mother walks, stands, sits, or lies down, it is like being bound by five ropes, or like being roasted by fire, difficult to bear and endure, with no analogy that can match it.
Nanda!
Although the fetus is in such a cesspool of filth with much pain and sharpness, due to sharp faculties, the mind is not scattered.

There is another type of sentient being with little merit, who in the mother's womb is either sideways or upside down. Due to the power of their past karma, or because the mother's diet of cold, hot, salty, sour, sweet, bitter, or pungent flavors is not well-regulated, or because she drinks water in excess, or engages in too much sexual activity, or has many illnesses, or is worried, or falls down, or is beaten, the mother's body becomes hot.
Because of the mother's heat, the fetus is also burned. Because of being burned, it experiences various sufferings. Because of having suffering, it then moves.
Because of moving, it may be sideways or upside down and unable to emerge.
There are skillful women who apply ghee and oil to their hands and enter the mother's womb, gently touching the fetus to settle it in its original position.
When the hands touch it, the fetus immediately experiences great suffering.
Nandana!
It is like a young boy or girl, a person cuts open their skin and flesh with a sharp knife and scatters ashes on it, causing great pain to arise.
The pain of the fetus is also like this.
Although they experience this pain, because of their sharp faculties, their right mindfulness is not scattered.
Nandottama!

The fetus dwells in the mother's womb like this, experiencing such suffering. Moreover, when about to be born, it suffers greatly and emerges. Due to karmic winds, the hands are crossed, the limbs and joints are clenched, and it experiences extremely intense suffering.

Desiring to emerge from the mother's womb, the body is bruised, like an initial swelling difficult to touch. Hungry and thirsty, the mind is filled with distress. Due to karmic conditions, it is pushed out by the wind.
Having emerged from the womb, it is touched by external winds as if being cut by burning embers. When touched by hands and clothes, it experiences extreme pain.
Although it experiences this pain, because of its sharp faculties, its right mindfulness is not confused.
In the mother's womb, it knows entering, dwelling, and emerging are all suffering. Nandottama!
Who would delight in entering such a womb?
Nan-t'o!
Who is it that, in the mother's womb, enters with right mindfulness and leaves with wrong mindfulness?
Nan-t'o!

It is like a certain class of ordinary beings who, by nature, delight in upholding precepts, cultivating wholesome qualities, always doing excellent things, and performing meritorious actions. Their minds are straightforward and they are not heedless, having little wisdom. At the time of death, they have no regrets. They may be stream-enterers with seven more rebirths, or those returning to lay life, or once-returners, or those with only one more birth.

This person, having previously cultivated wholesome conduct, at the time of death, although suffering and pain come to afflict them, their mind is not scattered, and they return to right mindfulness and enter the mother's womb. They understand that all phenomena are born from karma and arise from causes and conditions.

As explained above, up to leaving the womb, although experiencing such extreme suffering, because of having middling sharp faculties, they enter with right mindfulness and leave with wrong mindfulness.
As explained above, who would delight in entering such a womb?
Nan-t'o!
Who is one who enters the womb with right mindfulness, but is not right in abiding and coming out?
Nan-t'o!
It is like a certain class of ordinary beings who, by nature, delight in upholding precepts, cultivating wholesome qualities, always doing excellent things, and performing meritorious actions.

As explained above, up to the point of having no regrets at the time of death, or being a stream-enterer who is reborn seven times, and so on. At the time of the end of life, when suffering comes to afflict them, although they experience pain and distress, their minds are not distracted, and they return to right mindfulness and enter their mother's womb.
Because of this, due to their lower sharp faculties, they know when entering the womb, but do not know when abiding or coming out.
As explained above, up to the point of who would delight in entering such a womb?
Nan-t'o!
Who is one who is not right in entering, abiding, or coming out with right mindfulness?

It is like a certain type of ordinary sentient beings who delight in defiling pure precepts, do not cultivate wholesome practices, always do evil things and perform evil actions, have an untrustworthy mind and often act recklessly, lack wisdom, are greedy and stingy with wealth, always keep their hands clenched and cannot open them to give to others, always have expectations, their minds are not well-controlled, see things in a distorted way, and regret at the time of death. All unwholesome actions manifest before them.
When they are about to die, they are tormented by intense pain and distress, and their minds are in a state of confusion.
Due to the suffering and distress, they cannot remember who they are.
Where have they come from?
Where are they going now?
Nandi!
This is called having no right mindfulness at the three times.
Explained in detail as above.
Nandi!
These sentient beings are born among humans, although there are such immeasurable sufferings and afflictions, this is still a superior realm.
It is difficult to obtain a human body in immeasurable hundreds of thousands of koá¹­is of kalpas.
If reborn in the heavens, one always fears falling and has the suffering of separation from loved ones.
When life is about to end, other gods will say:
'May you be reborn in the good destinies of the human realm.'
What are the good destinies of the human realm?
It refers to humans and gods.
The human realm is difficult to obtain, and it is even more difficult to be free from difficult circumstances.
What are the evil destinies?
It refers to the three evil paths.
Those in the hells always experience intense suffering that is extremely unpleasant, with intense pain difficult to describe.
Those in the hungry ghost realm are mostly hateful and lack a gentle mind, deceitful and harmful with blood on their hands, without compassion and ugly in appearance, frightening to see;
Even if they approach humans, they suffer from hunger and thirst and are always obstructed.

As for the animal realm, there are countless and boundless beings who engage in meaningless actions, meritorious actions, Dharma actions, wholesome actions, and pure actions, and they devour each other, with the strong oppressing the weak.
There are some animals that are born, grow, and die all in the dark, filthy, and foul-smelling places of excrement and filth.
Sometimes there is a brief light, such as in the case of bees, butterflies, mosquitoes, ants, lice, fleas, and maggots.
There are also countless and boundless others that are born, grow, and always live in the dark.

This is because in their previous lives they were foolish people who did not listen to the scriptures and Dharma, indulged their body, speech, and mind, greedily attached to the five desires, and created many evil things. Born into this category, they experience the suffering of delusion.
Nanda!
There are also countless and boundless beings in the animal realm who are born, grow, and die all in the water, such as fish, turtles, alligators, frogs, and so forth.
This is due to the evil of body, speech, and mind in their previous lives, as explained in detail above.
Nanda!

There are also innumerable and boundless animals who, upon smelling the fragrance of feces and urine, quickly go there to eat and drink, namely pigs, sheep, chickens, dogs, foxes, weasels, vultures, crows, flies, dung beetles, and other animals.
All of this is due to the evil karma they have attracted in their previous lives, and they receive such retribution.
Nanda!
There are also innumerable and boundless animals who always use grass, trees, and impurities to fill their food and drink, namely elephants, horses, camels, cows, donkeys, and mules.
Until the end of their lives, due to their previous evil karma, they receive such retribution.
Furthermore, Nanda!
The sea of suffering in birth and death is painful indeed!
The raging flames burn fiercely and are extremely hot, and not a single sentient being is not burned and cooked.
All of this is due to the raging and fierce fires of the eyes, ears, nose, tongue, body, and mind, greedily seeking the objects of form, sound, smell, taste, touch, and mental objects.
Nanda!
What is called raging and fierce fire?

Namely, the fires of greed, anger, and delusion, the fires of birth, old age, sickness, and death, the poisonous and harmful fires of worry, sorrow, suffering, and distress, constantly burning on their own, with no one able to escape.
Nanda!
Lazy people suffer much, entangled by afflictions, creating unwholesome dharmas, cycling without rest, with no end to birth and death.
Diligent people experience much happiness, giving rise to a courageous mind, cutting off afflictions, cultivating wholesome dharmas, not abandoning the yoke of goodness, with no time to rest.
Therefore, you should now contemplate this body, the skin, flesh, sinews, bones, blood vessels, and marrow, which will soon disintegrate.
Always be single-minded, do not be lazy, and diligently seek realization for what has not yet been realized.
This is how you should learn.
Nanda!
I do not engage in disputes with the world, yet the world forcefully disputes with me.
Why is this?
Those who understand the Dharma do not dispute with others, free from the self and what belongs to the self, with whom can they have discussions?
Because of giving rise to false grasping without insight, I attained perfect enlightenment and made this statement: 'I have no lack of understanding regarding all dharmas.'
Nan-t'o!
Is there any difference in what I have said?
Nan-t'o said:
No, World-Honored One!
The Tathagata's words are without difference.
The Buddha said:
Excellent, excellent!
Nan-t'o!
The Tathagata's words are definitely without difference.

The Tathagata is the one who speaks truth, speaks reality, speaks as it is, speaks without difference, speaks without deception, wishing to cause the world to attain great benefit and peace for a long time.

He is the one who knows the path, the one who recognizes the path, the one who speaks of the path, the one who opens the path, the great guide, the Tathagata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One, the One of Perfect Understanding and Action, the Well-Gone One, the Knower of the World, the Unsurpassed One, the Tamer of Men, the Teacher of Gods and Men, the Buddha, the World-Honored One.

The people of the world are ignorant and lack faith. They are always slaves to the senses, only seeing what is in their palms and not considering the great benefits. They do not cultivate easy matters but always do difficult ones.
Nanda!
Stop at this wisdom realm.
You should now observe with the flesh eyes what you see, knowing that what is seen is all false, and that is called liberation.
Nanda!

Do not believe in me, do not follow my desires, do not rely on my words, do not observe my appearance, do not follow the views of the Å›ramaá¹‡a, do not give rise to reverence for the Å›ramaá¹‡a, do not say:
'The Å›ramaá¹‡a Gautama is my teacher.
' However, you can only contemplate and observe the Dharma that I have realized by myself in a quiet place, and always cultivate it extensively.

According to the dharmas that one observes with one's mind, one accomplishes the contemplation of those dharmas, abides in right mindfulness, makes oneself an island, makes oneself a refuge, takes the Dharma as an island, takes the Dharma as a refuge;
there is no other island, no other refuge.
Nanda!
How does a bhiká¹£u make himself an island, make himself a refuge, take the Dharma as an island, take the Dharma as a refuge;
without another island, without another refuge?
Thus, Nanda!

If there is a bhiká¹£u who abides contemplating the internal body, diligently, clearly knowing, fixing the mind, in the various worldly resentments and afflictions always thinking to subdue them, this is called contemplating the internal body as suffering.
If one contemplates the external body and the internal and external body, it is also like this.
Nanda!

Next, regarding the dharmas of accumulation, abiding in the observation of the body, abiding in the observation of cessation, and again abiding in the observation of the body in the two dharmas of accumulation and cessation, then being able to have right mindfulness regarding this body, either having only knowledge, or only having insight, or only having mindfulness without support, knowing that there is nothing to grasp in this world.
Thus, Nanda!
This is called a bhiká¹£u abiding in the observation of his own inner body.
The observation of the outer body and the inner and outer body is also like this.

Next, abiding in the observation of inner feelings, outer feelings, and inner and outer feelings, abiding in the observation of the inner mind, the outer mind, and the inner and outer mind, abiding in the observation of inner dharmas, outer dharmas, and inner and outer dharmas.

With diligence, mindfulness, and correct understanding, they always contemplate taming the anger and vexation in the world. They contemplate the abiding of the arising of dharmas and the cessation of dharmas, and again contemplate the dharmas of the arising and cessation of the two dharmas and abide in them. They are able to correctly recollect this body, with only wisdom, only views, or only mindfulness. In this world, they know there is nothing to grasp.
Thus, Nanda!
This is called a bhiká¹£u who is his own island, his own refuge, with the Dharma as his island, the Dharma as his refuge;
without another island, without another refuge.
Nanda!

If there is a man who is honest by nature, far from flattery and deception, who comes to me in the morning, and I teach him the good Dharma according to his capacity, he himself declares what he has attained in the evening;
in the evening I teach the Dharma, and in the morning he declares what he has attained.
Nanda!ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
My good Dharma is presently realized and able to remove afflictions. It is well-suited to the times and easily accessible. It is the Dharma of self-realization and is well-protected.
Having heard the Dharma I have spoken in person, one accords with quiescence and is able to progress towards enlightenment.
This is what I know.
Therefore, you should now always cultivate and study the dharmas that are seen to be beneficial to oneself, beneficial to others, and beneficial to both.

In the Dharma of going forth, be careful in practice and do not let it pass in vain. You will attain supreme fruits, unconditioned peace and happiness, and receive others' offerings of clothing, food, bedding, and medicine, causing the donors to obtain great blessings and virtues, and attain supreme fruits that are noble and vast.
Thus, Nanda!
You should cultivate and study.
Furthermore, Nanda!
There is not a single form that is lovable and enjoyable, which in the future will not change and decay. There is no such possibility.
It is also impossible not to give rise to sorrow and lamentation, and not to give rise to suffering and distress.
Nandika!
What do you think?
Is this form permanent?
Or is it impermanent?
Venerable One!
Its essence is impermanent.
Nandika!
Since its essence is impermanent, is it suffering or not?
Venerable One!
It is suffering.
If it is impermanent and suffering, then it is subject to change.

Do my many learned noble disciples consider form to be the self, do they consider the self as possessing form, do they consider form as belonging to the self, or do they consider the self to be in form?
He said:
No, World-Honored One!
